content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Totally doable in time.

The definition of "recognizable" maybe a little bit confusing since the brain kinda skips "in every 3x3 area". I would suggest putting this part further so it's something like "A character is recognizable if there is no 3x3 area in which a number of differences from the matrix of X is bigger than 1." I would also like an example but that may be a little too much. Figuring out is a fun process too, not for everyone tho.

The real reason why I can't approve this is the output format.
If it's Shortest I would not recommend using 'true'/'false or 'True'/'False' since it favors one language over another.
Of course, not everything needs to be balanced but here you can just change it to 'recognizable'/'not recognizable' or 'Recognizable'/'Not recognizable'. It'll not only save some salt but will also enable tricks like `${r?`Not r`:`R`}ecognizable`.

I like the challenge, I think the description needs work. 
Unclear that the X is always formed by '#' and the white space is always '.'

What about this phrasing:
if the number of differences >from the above example< is max 1...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good to me! It might've been a little more interesting if the target to match were variable, but I  suppose that wouldn't change the puzzle in any meaningful way.

Your validators are identical to the test cases.
They need to be different, to prevent hard-coded solutions.

Not sure you can use this for speed clash since the concept of Hamming distance is not that widely spread. Looks more like a easy solo training for me.

By the way, it's Hamming, not Hemming.
Addition of test cases is in progress.
The concept of Hamming distance is just a reference to the simple concept of number of differences.
Thanks, I assumed this, but now I am sure. :)

I completely agree. The coding would need less typing as well.

I chose the explicit X target, because
the less abstract statement is easier to understand
and it is less work to text, :)
I think.

- "Unclear that the X is always formed by '#' and ...":

There are in the text:
"A character is given in a 5x5 matrix of '.' or '#'."
and
"The X character is:"
So, it says that the given character consists of '#' and '.' and how is the X character defined. These are definitions.
There is no "white space" in the character.
Why do you think that the "X character" can be something else?

- "if the number of differences >from the above example< is max 1":

This is the definition of "a character is recognizable", so I would not use the term "example" instead "the number of differences from the matrix of X".

It is a general rule: the negation like in the suggested definition may make understanding more difficult. 

What I think a disadvantage of Clash f Code is that it motivates us to use expressions like `f'{"R" if result else "Not r"}ecognizable'`.
If one would like to search for a log message in a big project, good luck to find it, if it is put together form multiple pieces.

What about "yes" / "no"?

> the negation like in the suggested definition may make understanding more difficult.
It's better than dragging Max into this tho.
Generally "if there is no" translates better to the actual algorithm.
At least change  "is max 1 in every 3x3 area" to "is less than two..." or "less or equal 2...". As it is now it's the most off-putting and confusing part of the statement.


>If one would like to search for a log message in a big project, good luck to find it, if it is put together form multiple pieces.
Well, you shouldn't write code in big projects as if you're playing golf. 
But I get what you're saying and if you don't want to encourage those practices then I fully support you.

> What about "yes" / "no"?
Yea, it'll work I think.


Also, I would recommend changing "The <<X>> character is:" to "The <<matrix of X>> character is:" so players can more easily draw a connection to it.
And changing "A character is recognizable, ..." to "The given character is recognizable, ...". or at least "A character is recognizable as X,..."

I think the discussion about the definition in the description is about style.
It is short, a single conditional sentence and can be understood.

Now, with the expected "yes" or "no" no language is favoured.

The "A character" -> "The given character" also makes the sentence more pre-digested.

> ...discussion about the definition in the description is about style.
Nuh. "...is max 1 in every 3x3 area." is straight-up confusing.
You can understand it, yes, but it's not as clear as it can be.

Also, guidelines got updated and now it's recommended to avoid binary output formats entirely.
If you can change it so a player wouldn't get 50% just by outputting 'yes' or 'no' it would be appreciated. Something like adding a count of all differences to the output can do the trick.
